title: RS22831
content: In 2007, Russian President Vladimir Putin faced the decision of stepping down or abolishing term limits. He endorsed Dmitriy Medvedev as his successor, reassuring Russians that the "Putin plan" would continue. Medvedev, who had worked closely with Putin since 2000, was appointed as the next president, with Putin accepting the role of prime minister under his presidency. Dmitriy Medvedev, endorsed by Putin as his successor, implemented high-budget national projects and held the chairmanship of Gazprom. In the 2008 presidential election, four candidates registered, with Medvedev, Zyuganov, and Zhirinovskiy nominated by Duma parties. Other candidates faced challenges in gathering signatures, with Kasyanov denied registration and Kasparov's group facing obstacles in nominating him. Nemtsov, nominated by the Union of Right Forces Party, received approval from the Central Electoral Commission. Oppositionist Garry Kasparov faced obstacles in renting halls for a meeting to nominate him as a candidate. Boris Nemtsov, nominated by the Union of Right Forces Party, received approval to gather signatures but ended his campaign, citing government interference. Andrey Bogdanov, a candidate from the pro-Putin Democratic Party, gathered two million signatures and was approved. Medvedev refused to debate other candidates, claiming their programs had no chance of implementation. Golos found Medvedev received overwhelming TV coverage in regions they monitored. Zyuganov and Zhirinovskiy complained about unequal TV coverage, leading to slightly more coverage for Zyuganov. During pre-election monitoring, Medvedev received extensive television coverage. Zyuganov and Zhirinovskiy filed complaints about unequal TV coverage, leading to slightly more coverage for Zyuganov. Putin and Medvedev outlined long-term development programs, emphasizing stability and prosperity compared to the 1990s. Medvedev's speech focused on judicial reforms, media independence, and combating corruption. He called for protecting the independence of the media to enable free expression and expose corruption. Medvedev emphasized the need for independent courts and media, protection of private property rights, equal access to healthcare and education, and the possibility of home ownership. He won 70.28% of the votes, with observers noting Zyuganov and Zhirinovskiy's increased support. Observers noted that Zyuganov and Zhirinovskiy benefitted from their runner-up results in the election, with Zyuganov claiming election "rigging" denied him extra votes. Bogdanov conceded defeat quickly, while Zhirinovskiy pledged support for the new president. The OSCE ODIHR declined to monitor the election due to Russian government restrictions. The OSCE ODIHR declined to monitor the Russian presidential election due to Russian government restrictions. A monitoring group from PACE described the election as more of a plebiscite on Putin's rule than a competitive election. Concerns were raised about the onerous registration process for independent candidates and uneven media coverage affecting the electoral process. Amendments to electoral legislation in 2005 banned electoral observers from NGOs. McFaul described the Russian presidential election as the least competitive in post-communist history. Amendments in 2005 restricted electoral observers to candidates' representatives and media only. Golos, despite obstacles, monitored voting precincts. Putin congratulated Medvedev and announced plans to restructure the government before Medvedev's inauguration on May 7. Medvedev viewed the election results as an endorsement of Putin's policies. Putin directed ministries to develop detailed plans following the election. Putin congratulated Medvedev on his election victory and immediately convened a cabinet meeting to direct ministries to work on implementing development goals for 2020. He called for plans to promote finished goods processing of natural resources, strengthen the home mortgage and banking systems, and streamline rules for small businesses. Observers suggest Putin will retain power while Medvedev may have a ceremonial role as president. Putin emphasized the need to find revenues to cover increased social benefits. Putin is expected to retain power while Medvedev will have a ceremonial role as president. Putin will have substantial powers as prime minister, including formulating budgets, monetary policy, and addressing social issues. There is speculation that Medvedev was chosen to not interfere with policies benefiting Putin's associates. Some analysts believe Medvedev may assert himself slowly against these associates, potentially leading to democratization. Medvedev may assert himself against the "siloviki" to create a better balance of powers between institutions. Analysts predict potential clashes between Putin and Medvedev due to their different leadership roles. Inter-bureaucratic clashes are a concern as both leaders navigate their respective positions. Alexander Voloshin, Putin's former chief of staff, predicts clashes between Putin and Medvedev due to their different leadership roles. Concerns arise about inter-bureaucratic clashes paralyzing the government, reminiscent of the dual power centers in 1993. Medvedev faces domestic challenges such as sustaining the economic boom, rising inflation, terrorism, and civil disorder in the North Caucasus region. Opposition marches are met with force in Moscow, while pro-Putin groups are supported. On March 3, a march in St. Petersburg was held, while an unsanctioned demonstration in Moscow was dispersed. Medvedev announced a focus on foreign policy and accepted invitations to visit several countries. Russia voted in favor of new sanctions against Iranian uranium enrichment. Medvedev urged Ukrainian President Viktor Yushchenko to pay the country's gas debt. President Bush emphasized the importance of a personal relationship with Russia for future U.S. presidents. On March 4, Medvedev urged Ukrainian President Viktor Yushchenko to pay the country's gas debt. President Bush emphasized the importance of a personal relationship with a new Russian president, highlighting common interests in non-proliferation and Iranian nuclear issues. Bush also called Medvedev to continue cooperation on counter-terrorism, counter-proliferation, and other issues. Disagreements between the United States and Russia include U.S. missile defenses in Eastern Europe, Kosovo's independence, and NATO enlargement. Putin had previously threatened to consider targeting. Putin and Medvedev have disagreements with the United States on issues such as missile defenses in Eastern Europe, Kosovo's independence, and NATO enlargement. Medvedev's involvement with Gazprom suggests a focus on economic relations with Europe, potentially using energy as a political weapon. Gazprom's reduction of gas supplies to Ukraine on March 3 indicates a continuation of this policy. German Chancellor Angela Merkel predicts continuity in Russia's relations with the West under Medvedev. Russian analyst Alexey Pushkov argues that U.S. policy analysts have focused on the negative ramifications of increased authoritarianism in Russia under Putin, rather than on Russia's growing economic stability. Andrey Illarionov, Putin's former economic advisor, warns that recent Russian actions indicate a unique historical "siloviki dictatorship" and that Medvedev has used his legal background to reverse democratization in the country. Alexey Pushkov and Andrey Illarionov discuss the negative impact of authoritarianism in Russia under Putin, with Illarionov warning of a "siloviki dictatorship" under Medvedev reversing democratization. Recent Russian actions like cyber attacks and the poisoning of Litvinenko are cited as examples of this regime.
